respondOpen_1:
I would want to address it with the employee. First, I would want to reflect and gather my thoughts on my perspective on the situation. Is there an actual performance issue, or does the employee just seem less enthusiastic and less happy at work? If a performance problem, I would want to make sure I have data or specific examples so I can explain what I am seeing and what I expect to see--eventually.

First, though, I would have a conversation with the employee about how things are going in general. What motivates them about their job, what's going well, what isn't, what they want to do more and less of, and how things have been going since I started. Depending on the employee's receptivity, I might mirror back at this point that I have noticed them seeming a bit disconnected, and open the door for more conversation about that, if there is anything they want to share, or need support with, but mostly I want to get a better sense of what the employee is feeling about their work.

From that conversation, I would have a better understanding of what's going on with the employee, and could make a plan from there to meet them where they're at.

I would not treat disengagement itself as a performance issue that needs to be managed. It's not required for an employee to be enthusiastic and go above and beyond all the time. If this employee is deprioritizing work but still achieving expectations, that's allowed and something I would support. But I do want to probe and understand if there's something in my control that would help them feel more connected at work.

So, I would challenge myself to assume neutral or good intentions and focus on bridging our communication gap as a problem-solving exercise. Some things I might try could be: making sure I have regular 1:1s with the manager, and making sure I am asking about how things are going for them and what they're working on. If I had a colleague I trusted, I might ask them for some feedback to see if they also notice what I'm noticing, that it doesn't seem like I'm connecting very well with the new manager, and if they have any reflections on what seems to resonate with this manager that I could try.

I don't think I would start the conversation with my manager with the big picture of feeling a little forgotten, at least not for a couple of months until they're a little more settled in and past the drinking-from-a-fire-hose stage. However, whenever I'm left off a meeting or similar, I would make sure to mention it, neutrally and non-judgmentally.

If after several weeks/months, this still seems to be the situation, I would use a scheduled check in to highlight my concerns, and ask what it looks like from the manager's perspective too. I would emphasize that I want to have a positive relationship, so if there are things that I can do differently, I am open to doing so. This isolation can created uncertainty, even if the individual is doing well and respected by others the lack of communication can cause the individual to question themselves. In addition some environments do not foster connections amongst peers, some workplace environments are competitive and interpersonal conflict is fostered by managers who tend to treat work as a competition and not a collaboration. An environment where employees feel that they have to fight for their position naturally creates distrust between individuals, even if they are not in direct conflict individuals want to appear as the "best" and sometimes this leads to them purposefully dsidelining others who they feel a threat to their position or putting down others as a way to increase their own preved statute within the organization. Even in smaller units where there is supposed to be close collaboration between two or more individuals the teams sometimes do not work if there is a belief of "us against the world" and if the team feels threatened it may work to oust or sideline their own members out of fear of them holding back their accomplishments. For example I witnessed an individual with a motor disability being ostracized and pulled off a lead position in a group project because their typing speed was seen as a indication that they were not qualified for the task, even though the task was analytical and not clerical in nature. The reasoning was that the individual would harm the perception of this group in the eyes of others harming the other members, even though this was not true.
manager2: For me I have been both a manager and a line employee at the UC. Also as mentioned previously there is a management school of thought that treats meaningless metrics such as typing speed as important to positions where it is clearly not important. employee1a: I have been both manager and employee at UC and the results of the first survey seem in line with my experience here. By talking to managers and having them be open about their job responsibilities and having them explain the motivations behind decisions a trustful relationship can start to grow. Often managers tend to not be as open as they can be to their employees, this creates mistrust and an adversarial relationship where employees often do not know why they are doing something and when that happens their engagement with the work is diminished. The manager may be facing pressure from all around and getting conflicting instructions from above and this can translate to the work assigned to the employees, by being open to talking to the employees the manager may be able to find solutions to their own work problems and with that the employees feel that they have made contributions to the work as well, this collaborative approach to not only employee but managers problems can increase trust.
